reviewText:
So... Here is a serious review for a change.

First of i wanted to say that now i have only done Rise's route and it was amazing. (Will update once i've done more) (Have finished it but I'm to lazy to update, If you got any questions feel free to add me and ask or just comment below)

So where to begin... Well this game is a Visual Novel that has humor, drama, love, and some serious stuff aswell.

The jokes in this game are fantastic they made me laugh out loud and brightend my mood from the serious matters. Beatiful art AND soundtrack. This game also has voice acting, and not just some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice acting. It is really good. It took me 18hours to complete Rise's route and that is good time for a route imo (i consider myself a fast reader so it might take longer.) I dont really know what more i should say it's really good, in 2days i played it for 18hours (amazing? nah i should just get a life.) The length of this game is quite impressive as stated before and that to me alongside everything it is worth the price, dont let the price tag scare you. The only negative thing i can think of is there aren't many choices but they aren't really needed just feels kinda weird is all.

Aand if you are 18+ and want a copy of the 18+ version you can buy it from here (you also get a steam key for the game) http://www.mangagamer.com/detail.php?goods_type=1&product_code=117 (NSFW, NUDITY ON THIS PAGE)

reviewText:
Princess Evangile is a romantic-comedy-drama story. It’s based around the protagonist, Masaya, being accepted into a school of all girls, as a test for possible gender integration. It made it fun to read and enjoyable from start to finish.

The storyThe story itself, including individual routes as well as the common, was well written. It flowed nicely, It's a pretty lengthy story, and it felt worth the price.

Audio and Visual elementsThe audio and visual elements were great, It sets the mood and feel like it belongs in the situation and the environment, especially the heroine themes. The backgrounds and CGs were beautiful and detailed.

There  full Japanease audio for all of the girls, and side characters combined with a well fitting soundtrack. The game also tends to use alot of French words for naming stuff, but there is the option to click on them and get a detailed explanation for the meaning.

Routes and PathingAs for the routes/heroines, they all felt different from each other. They all had their individual quirks that made them stand out and likeable. Their routes all had happy moments and depressing moments. It’s hard not to get invested in a character emotionally when they have so much detail put into them.


To sum upPrincess Evangile is well worth the money. The characters are likable to keep you interested in the game and wanting to finish their routes, the story is silly to grab people's attention fast, and the H-Scenes are well tied to the story and didn't feel out of place.

Click here for the full review![azusantiara.wordpress.com]

reviewText:
The question you're probably asking is whether this game is worth $35. The answer to that is subjective of course, but I generally say that a game is worth it if I get 1 hour per dollar. I know that's a bit of a cop out answer, so here's my actual review

Is the game good?
Yes
Is the game great?
Debatable, visual novels are somewhat different from most games in that the order you do the routes in them actually does have a significant impact on your experience. I did Ayaka's route first which made the other routes suck by comparison.

The game has a good sense of humour, and made me really laugh, like laughing hard enough for my head to touch my desk funny. That humour is one of the selling points. This is a feel-good VN, there are some darker parts to it, but for the most part it's supposed to make you smile.

That is an issue in some respects though, the game was enjoyable and entertaining. It was not however terribly touching (except one part of Ayaka's route brought tears to my eyes... her route is the best by far). Of the four romances:

One was cheesy (Ritsuko's was too ridiculous to ever take seriously)
One was pure vanilla extract (Rise's route... of course hers was also the funniest because they openly made fun of how over-the top vanilla it was. The drama felt a little forced though, and the romance overall felt unrealistic.)

One was good (Chiho's route was fairly standard, but had an actually realistic romance progression, [ it took two ♥♥♥♥ing months after declaring undying love for eachother in Rise and Ritsuko's routes for the first kiss] and was fairly exciting)

One was very good (Ayaka's route had stellar character development, she seems like an interesting character and winds up being interesting in ways completely different from your expectations. All development is explained logically and I felt this was the most realistic route due to the interal conflict and difficulty they had expressing their feelings... I mean come on, it's not easy to ask someone out, let alone confess your love to them before the first date).

Do I regret buying it, since 2 routes weren't my cup of tea?
No. Rise's wasn't bad per-se, it just wasn't to my taste, some people will like it, and some people even liked Ritsuko's route, in this kind of game, there will always be some contention when ranking routes and saying what was subjectively better. The forums do seem to agree that Ayaka's route is the best though, and it is.

Ritsuko's route was kinda like Mega Pirhana, one of those cheap ♥♥♥ Sci-Fi channel movies that are just hilariously bad. I couldn't really tell if the dev's were taking it seriously or not, but I wound up laughing during the climax (of the plot... the game is censored, but they did a really good job of it so I'm not complaining) which makes it a failure in my book.

The fact of the matter is that I got my money's worth, and would buy the fandisc if it came to Steam (assuming it was at or under $15)

As I mentioned before, order matters, I would reccomend Chiho's route first, then Rise/Ritsuko and end with Ayaka for maximal enjoyment.

Overall I'd give it a 7.5 / 10
Worth playing, but not the best thing since sliced bread.

reviewText:
8/10. Recommended.

Princess Evangile is primarily a dating simulator, this can be quite boring if it's not what you're looking for. In terms of a visual novel the story is amazing, each route will throw you into a violent rollercoaster of emotions. I'd be lying if I said I didn't cry at each one, both for happiness and despair. The music is wonderful and the whole story is good. Each route is different yet so gripping you won't want to stop.

The stories are evil, they will twist your heart in ways you've never known before.
Ritsuko-chan for best waifu.

Very recommended. Wonderful artwork, certainly value for money. The translation also uses very advanced English and some French, so be prepared to have google open.

reviewText: It's hard to say goodbye to Vincennes.  For two months this place has been like a second home, filling my nights and weekends with the joys and sorrows of youth.  After the toughest and longest days and weeks at work it was always there waiting for me, never asking too much but providing so much in return.  We have been through so much together.  Knowing this is the end, that there is no more, is really sad.\n\nI bought the 18+ version on mangagamer.  None of the 18+ scenes really alter the story at all, so the steam version should be just as fine without them.  The story is linear with four main paths, but at 26 chapters it is quite lengthy.  I am a little disappointed that you cannot date the cutest girl in the game (Mitsuki), but there's a lot of variety to the story in the paths that are there.  In my dreams, there is a special edition of the game that opens up more paths, but since that won't become a reality I can just hope the alleged sequel gets localized as well.  Vincennes is a place I would like to revisit someday.

reviewText:
2D > 3D

This has become one of my favorites. It has pretty much everything I look for in a visual novel. It finds a perfect balance between drama, romance and comedy.
The story for the routes are very well written and it's easy to get emotionally attached to the characters.
It's quite expensive for a visual novel, but it's worth it. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
This visual novel explores what hapens when woman have acquired large amount of power and riches. They controll large parts of the country, and men live in bitter poverty and are forced to turn to crime to feed their communitys.
In this VN with multiple routes we explore this cruel world trough the eyes of Okonogi Masaya, our male protagonist.
Masaya is a warior and master of various martial arts, and his mision is to infiltrate a high security feminist training camp.
you have only a few contacts on the inside but danger lurks around every corner and you have to be very carefull.
your goal is to break the feminist propoganda machine while fighting for the right for men to be educated as equals.

10/10 this game deserves a nobel prize

reviewText:
It's like watching an anime.
If you enjoy slice-of-life or romantic comedy anime, you'll probable like this VN.
The game is very simple. You just read and make some important choices to reach an ending.
The jokes are hilarious. I've always found myself laughing while reading.
The art is beautiful. The music is amazing. Voice acting is very good for me. (though some might consider it annoying)

The first playthrough is about 35-40 hours depends on how fast you read. (or just want to listen)
The common route is roughly about 25 hours and each girl's route is about 10 hours.
So the subsequent playthroughs will be much shorter as there is a skip button for already read dialogues. There's almost no way to get a bad end if you don't intentionally choose wrong choices.

If you like VNs or romantic comedy anime, there's no reason not to get this game.

P.S. I've cleared all routes in the 18+ version and decided to compare with this version.
I've only cleared Ritsuko's route in this version. This is my conclusion.

Even though this Steam version is All Ages Version, sex do happen in this game but it is not shown directly.

Some dialogues and CGs that got altered from the 18+ versions.
Panties got changed into bloomers in this version.
Yes, it's All Ages but who wears bloomers in her bedroom?

Some CGs may appear inconsistent with the text on-screen because of the altering.
Don't misunderstand, it's not censorship. It's just what this version is when it was released on the PSP.

I'd like to say that sex scenes are replaced by new content but that is not really true.
The new content is so little that it doesn't really matter. It doesn't add on the story or character dervelopment so don't expect to find much more content here if you've already cleared the 18+ version.

Only really downside is only 4 of the 9 gilrs that have an in depth involvment have a route, despite at least a few of those other ones really, really seeming like it was builing up to one.   Thankfully there is a spin off, if you will, that covers those 5 girls, and the company said that they will localise it if this does well enough, so to all that like this I implore you either but the the steam version or adult one from the company itself, whichever one youd prefer, since not only is it only a ggod VN thats got alot written into the sotry, but then we can get all are favorite girls ^_~

reviewText:
I'm not sure what to say that hasn't already been said about this visual novel. It's a just a good, light hearted moege (Google this if you don't know what it means) that totally won me over.

The description is pretty spot on, you're the only guy at an all-girls Catholic school. Antics ensue, fun is had. Four different endings are available, and all pretty unique. I won't spoil anything more, but...I do wish that the other heroines got more screen time. You'll see what I mean when you play it.

If you bought the MangaGamer version (like I did), the files are encrypted on both the MG and Steam versions. You cannot copy over the MG version and have Steam run it, unless you're okay with restarting Steam every time. Also, don't move your installation files, it will wipe your saves.

Overall, this is a good one if you are into moege. Price is a bit high (now), but I felt I got my money's worth.


P.S. Get the MangaGamer version if you want the removed content. It comes with a Steam key as well.

reviewText:
IGNORE MY PLAY TIME - THAT IS FOR THE STEAM VERSION...
Lets start off by saying this, I did get both versions of the game.

Without a doubt, this is probably one of the best Visual Novels I have ever played/read.
The story is really enticing, wanting to draw the reader in with each progression.

I have done all of the routes available at the moment, and I have to admit, I am really couldn't decide on what I would choose to be the best one. I really like Rise-sans Route, but Chiho is just as good. I'm an indecisive ba*****d. You really can not go wrong when choosing either of the many different routes. Just make sure to chose the same girl all the way through or you WILL regret it.

You will definatly get your moneys worth buying this game, with PLENTY of replay value. (Although I reccomend getting if from MangaGamer since you get both versions for around £2 more)

Pros:
Multiple Story Endings
Detailed Story Lines
Artwork
Music - Seriously, it is fantastic
All different types of personalities, ie: Tsundere

Cons:
No real cons, just nitpicks really,

Needs additional routes for the other girls (All though that has been solved with a Fandisk that is in the process of being translated, YAY!!! - Princess Evangile W/ Happiness)
Would be nice to be animated, but I really don't mind.

reviewText: Now I know the price then seeing the all ages version is a huge turn off but here this review out\nPERSONALITY yes main character is an actual character this is pretty uncommon in VN but not only that but he has an amazing backstory that even got me someone who is a huge otaku.\nStory is about a poor dude who basically goes to a all girls school after rescuing a damsel in distress and eh needs to earn his keep there because eh is part of an experiment to see if the school wants to become a mixed school or stay all girls(Yes only sample and one test not a good way to test it but hey). He meets people he knows there thats why he has friends he is mostly hated at first by majority of girls but yea through character development and plot it shines to light. Now its long now I finish VN relatively fast so about 16 hours for me for one ending(multiple endings depends on choices) but I see average being 30 for most people. All character are very charming and likable and some are just too lovable like asako and ruriko. Soundtrack is good as well as art very superb but because its the all ages version no hentai or patch BUT it actually replaces scenes with other that are not in the adult only version so even if you played the adult version you would want to see the scenes plus there is always google you could see what you missed. Overall great game 9.5 out of ten and just shouting out a great VN on steam if your looking for story rich almost about to cry worth your money check out a VN called eden its great you can get the original version here they did make some hentai version of it but the original make had none so get the one on steam.

Even though I've only completed one route, I can say without a doubt that this visual novel was a beautiful creation. It took me about 25 hours to complete, but at least one or two of those hours was leaving the VN on when I was away.

The story and characters are well made, and even though there are plenty of cliches that are found in Japanese media, I couldn't stop for long. I fully intend to do the other routes, but the route I finished (Ayaka's) was amazing, and I want to spread out the awesomeness this VN has over a moderate period of time.

11/10.

reviewText:
Now I know you will see that I have like no time on this game, but I bought the game from Mangagamer so I got a steam key. Ahem, now lets get to the review


I have only completed one route in the game and it took me a very long time to do it, despite being a very fast reader. I finished it in 15-20 hours. I can't give an exact time as steam doesn't keep track of your time in non-steam games. I would reccommend this to anyone who likes Visual Novels.


The story line is really amazing as it doesn't focus on the whole eroge genre of it. It takes almost the whole game for you to reach any girl. I think it's worth a 9/10 for now as I've only done one route in terms of the story.


As for the art and animation, its a simple design, some scenes have motion all the time, while others only change the characters posistion/eyes of them. I would've really liked full motion in the game for the price I paid, but its still good. 8/10 on that part.

Choices in the game are really simple, they ask you to pick who you want to go after outright. They aren't as often as you would think which I really liked as it added more indepth information about characters. I actually had to go back to a previous save after picking a girl, realizing when I had more info about one of them that I'd rather go that route instead. 10/10 on that part.


Overall this is the best Visual Novel I've read, giving it a solid 9/10 even a 10/10 perhaps when I finish all the routes.

reviewText:
Princess Evangile is a beautiful novel, with an amazing story and wonderful graphics. Great characters, all well developed. The only problem I had was that it ended. There is a huge backstory to the visual novel, which is revealed as the player progresses through the story.

The endings are all great (apart from when none of the routes are chosen/followed) and the whole story is very emotional, while still managing to maintain an air of humour throughout most of the novel.

Rating:

Characters: 10/10
Endings: 10/10
Routes (Story): 10/10
Backstory: 10/10

Overall: 10/10
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Personally, Princess Evangile stands out to me as a Drama/Romance VN that has some 'questionable' scenes (Which aren't included on steam due to reasons) but even without those scenes it is a great Visual Novel with a great story and great characters

At the point of me writing this review I've only cleared Ayaka's route but what I can say from it is that Character development is a HUGE part of the story.
The protagonist is Masaya Okonogi (I've typed it the English way so leave it be) who stumbles upon a girl being approached by a group of uniformed women, from there his life changes for the better (I know it's cliched but bear with it)

It would also be a lie if I said that I didn't get emotionally attached to the Characters because of learning about their past, each route giving more and more backstory and character development which is standard for a romance based VN.

Basically as of now I believe that this game definately is worth the price which you paid for and a good investment for people who wish to spend hours and hours reading and connecting with the characters or just want something interesting to read in their spare time!

reviewText:
Male Shaming Simulator; With a side order of romance and drama
Considering you got 26 Chapters, full Japanese Voice acting with a believable, yet emotional story. If you sit there and listen to it all, it'll easily last you for 40+ hours and you know what? This game's worth the price (to get the Adult Version, get it from MangaGamer as these files are encrypted).

While I can't help that the main and minor female characters you interact with all fall into a hard stereotype blended into their personalities, it's at least done with style. While the school life adventure has been done numerous amounts of time, this one shows promise and delivers. It balances some romance, humor, drama, and the in-betweens of an adolescene well, and it executes those themes brillantly. This particular visual novel also left me with a color pallete of many emotions. At the same time, because of its drawn out length, this visual novel will have some holes that I will critique it for. There's also the 'version' debuncle that I want to cover as well.

Characters
For those that are curious about the character 'archetypes', it goes something like this:

You see, you got Miss Rise"-and-Shine
voteText: the perky loli "Konomi"
votesTotal:
a well respected student lead "Marika" with her right hand lady "Mitsuki" who have an undying passion of righteousness.

What is the Deal with All Ages vs. Adult Only versions?
When I did some research
votesFunny: it seems as describing and showing 15-20 minutes of sexual content is defined as an Adult game and will not be allowed to sell according to their Steam Representative (source). The Adult Only version technically has more content than the All Ages version. Kudos to the developer for handling the PR aspects well as it was outside their control. Steam wouldn't allow the release of the Adult version nor a post-game patch (HuniePop is a grey area that was allowed a pass since the content wasn't as sexually explicit as this game is.)\n\nHowever
commentsCount: the MangaGamer store will offer you the All Ages key if you buy the "Adult Only" version on the website. Kudos again
column16:
developer.

Criticisms
- The branching paths you can take in this game are limited to one girl at a time
column17: and even then you can't explore some of the side characters.\n- The jokes in this game are actually pretty funny only if you haven't been exposed much within the Japan culture.\n- The music can get repetitive very fast
column18: especially going over 26 chapters... Oh no...\n- The 'Summer' chapters run like a typical episode in an anime/manga where it's summer break and the characters do their... Cheesy shenanigans.\n+ However
column19: the 'Main' chapters are executed well and each of the character's backstories are thorough and verbose. You are able to connect to everyone (whether you like them or hate them).\n? It has a lot of male shaming in it. Whether this is your fetish
column20:
or you'll get annoyed at considering it sounds similar to an uneducated feminist rant. That's up to you for interpretation.

Final Verdict
With a legnthy game and a fair share of shortcomings
column21:
it still has some questions to answer.
Is this a fun game? Definitely.
Does this game motivate you enough to explore the other options? It sure does if those archetypes caught your eye. Otherwise it can be debateable.
Is it a masterpiece? For the school-based Visual Novel junke
column22: it's high up there.\nBut the price! It's so much! I understand the complaint. You do get a lot of chapters
column24:
and the art's pretty nice to look at.
It's also a nice bonus that the Moonstone developers do reply.

It is safe to say it's a high recommendation from me. Now
column26: be man shamed and enjoy the experience."

reviewText: It's the literary equivalent of a pet rock. It feels like it was written by a 14 year old school girl. With antagonists confessing to their nefarious deeds in front of a crowd of people (thanks lady!) to an overreliance on chance solving the protagonist's problems at every turn that will make you cringe. The protagonist is 'practically perfect in every way' to the point of boredom. What makes Princess Evangile worth reading are the girls. Marika's self righteousness, Ruriko's innocence, Chiho's uncertainty, Ritsuko's faith, it's sad that they're not all available to 'win'. The endings are cliche, the scenes are contrived, the only surprises are what you'll learn about girls who have no contact with men. I imagine the writers had help from sisters or friends. It's the type of game you play because you like visual novels, you enjoy the art of Moonstone, and you want to enjoy a pleasant experience relaxing with friends, all of whom are girls. Overall I would recommend it to those who already like moe visual novels or anime. It's not a beginners visual novel but it's worth the read.

reviewText: I was on the fence about buying this. Seems to have good reviews here and elsewhere. The game description should have warned me away. Ultimately I assumed this would be more like a certain manga about a commoner sample". Technically speaking there's nothing wrong. Nice art
recommended:
good UI (some VNs seem to really skimp on the basics).

My problem is mostly with the story. The girls aren't just sheltered. Their naive to the point of being born in a cabbage field. That is to say they seem to know so little about males that I'd assume none of them had fathers or brothers. It's storyline is a contrived romp through anime/manga tropes that seems to be for the lulz. Except I think it takes itself a little too seriously.

The MC is almost as bad with a naivety of a different kind. Considering his background you'd think he'd be a little quicker on the uptake. Most of the conflict in the common route begins with him blundering into it.

Would not recommend unless you're really into by-the-numbers

reviewText:
After Playing an decent about of the Story here is my review of Princess Evagile.

You Play as the Protagonist Masaya, who after some family troubles, run in's with the Mob and lots of other unlucky situations his luck starts to change, He has been chosen to represent The Male Community in an Gender-intergation at an Private All-Girls School.....(Lucky Bas-A-Anyway moving on!)

The Game is set up into 26 chapter with 4 Possible Routes (Why can't we have an Harem Ending!)

The Game may appear Kinectic and slow at first with few choices, more or less these chatpers are for you to learn about the chararcters, but that is not an bad thing, the amount of Drama and storytelling during these chapters is byfar great and entertaining, even if an few may leave you laughing or crying.

The Voice acting is top notch each chararcter sounded great clear and perfect.

As for the Artwork the chararcter all had there own personal looks and style which made it nice to look at, and the CG Scenes during Events was really nice ranging from Full chararcter shots to cute little Chibi's.

The Music......my god the music is lovely every little OST of this game is great to listen to it really sets the mood right from ones that play in every day occurance, to the silly music when something stupid just happend to the tear-jerking sad moments, its just Perfect.

As for The Bad things about this game, there really are'nt any, the only nitpick i would have is that some of the main girls you see everyday are not Choices to be Routes but thats it XD

As for my Opinion Regradless of the Price i say this Game is an Must-Buy for Any Visual Novel Fan, it hits all the right marks.

reviewText: This is one of the best Visual Novels I have ever read. It may be a bit expensive but trust me, you will get your moneys worth, with 26 chapters plus 4 different routes within those chapters you are looking at  about 50 - 70 hours of reading this great novel. The writing for this navel was great with a well balanced set of characters and side characters. The story is fantastic as you build a connection to these characters as you read and will go through a series of different emotions such as anger, laughter, and you may even cry(literally, no joke). I would be lying if I said I didn't cry while reading this visual novel. The artwork is also fantastic with beautiful visuals as well as chibi art. The music is also great as it works great with this visual novel as it compliments the story at the right times as things get more serious or more comical. All in all, I would recommend this to anyone, especially if you are a fan of visual novels.\n10/10

reviewText: As a person who loves to read, I must say that Princess Evangile is one of the most beautifully crafted visual novels I've ever read. Every charater has their own story and is likeable in their own way. I easily grew attached to each one as they were introduced one way or another. This novel also holds a hefty 25+ chapters, making it one of the longest novels I've read. There's also some aspects of a choose your own adventure" story in here at certain intervals. While not too many of them are present in the story
date: they're placed at important intervals that can change the story in unique ways. I also must say that the writing in this novel is astounding. I found myself smiling
hoursPlayed: and even crying during many points of the story. Princess Evangile is one of those stories that's well worth the price
voteText: as well as also reading over for its four different endings. And yes

reviewText: I liked the game a lot more than I was expecting.  It was deeper and more compelling than I thought it would be, and while I have a few quibbles here and there over a few stories, the surprising depth of some, like Ayaka, was extremely intriguing.

voteText: January 18

reviewText:
*I've played this on another computer, so don't mind my hours.*

First, this is hands down my favorite visual novel of all time. I found it entertaining very well put together. Though, it does get repetitive in each route from time to time, but it also adds unique elements within them too.

Basically, this visual novel is about a teenage boy (Masaya, the MC) who pretty much grew up on the streets with his deadbeat father. They accumulated a large debt over time from the local yakuza/mafia and have been on the run for years. The father one day disappears and pushes the debt onto Masaya, who has been working months and months just for some extra cash. So, now Masaya has to find a way to clear his debt... while doing so conviently running into a rich teenage girl and conviently winning the lottery, thus clearing it up. After he clears his debt, the girl invites him to be the first and only male at an all girls highschool as a sample for future integration. Here on, lives his whole year within this highschool, falling in love and getting into trouble.

So, if you like cute, slice of life, school, romance kind of stuff, then I suggest checking this out. Whether it be the Steam version or the patched 18+ version, it is still a very good visual novel.
